<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Milk skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Milk</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-protected&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-protected (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-protected</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Milk.jpg" title="File:Milk.jpg">File:Milk.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A glass of <a href="/wiki/Pasteurization" title="Pasteurization">pasteurized</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cattle (page does not exist)">cow</a> milk</div></div></div>
<p><b>Milk</b> is a white liquid produced by the <a href="/wiki/Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland">mammary glands</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammals</a>. It is the primary source of <a href="/wiki/Nutrition" title="Nutrition">nutrition</a> for young mammals before they are able to <a href="/wiki/Digestion" title="Digestion">digest</a> other types of food. Early-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactation (page does not exist)">lactation</a> milk contains <a href="/wiki/Colostrum" title="Colostrum">colostrum</a>, which carries the mother's <a href="/wiki/Antibody" title="Antibody">antibodies</a> to the baby and can reduce the risk of many <a href="/wiki/Diseases" title="Diseases" class="mw-redirect">diseases</a> in the baby. It also contains many other nutrients.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>As an <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agricultural</a> product, milk is <a href="/wiki/Milking" title="Milking">extracted from mammals</a> during or soon after pregnancy and used as <a href="/wiki/Food" title="Food">food</a> for humans. Worldwide, <a href="/wiki/Dairy" title="Dairy">dairy</a> farms produced about 730 million tonnes of milk in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is the world's largest producer and consumer of milk, yet neither exports nor imports milk. <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>'s 28 member states, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> are the world's largest exporters of milk and milk products. <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> are the world's largest importers of milk and milk products.<sup id="cite_ref-Blasko_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blasko-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout the world, there are more than 6 billion consumers of milk and milk products. Over 750 million people live within dairy farming households. Milk is a key contributor to improving nutrition and food security particularly in developing countries. Improvements in livestock and dairy technology offer significant promise in reducing <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poverty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Types_of_consumption">Types of consumption</span></h2>
<p>There are two distinct types of milk consumption: a natural source of nutrition for all infant mammals and a food product for humans of all ages that is derived from other animals.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition_for_infant_mammals">Nutrition for infant mammals</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Woman_breastfeeding_an_infant.jpg" title="File:Woman breastfeeding an infant.jpg">File:Woman breastfeeding an infant.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">human</a> baby feeding on its mother's milk</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Goat_kid_feeding_on_mothers_milk.jpg" title="File:Goat kid feeding on mothers milk.jpg">File:Goat kid feeding on mothers milk.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Goat (page does not exist)">goat</a> kid feeding on its mother's milk</div></div></div>
<p>In almost all mammals, milk is fed to <a href="/wiki/Infant" title="Infant">infants</a> through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Breastfeeding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Breastfeeding (page does not exist)">breastfeeding</a>, either directly or by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Breastfeeding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Breastfeeding (page does not exist)">expressing</a> the milk to be stored and consumed later. The early milk from mammals is called <a href="/wiki/Colostrum" title="Colostrum">colostrum</a>. Colostrum contains <a href="/wiki/Antibodies" title="Antibodies" class="mw-redirect">antibodies</a> that provide protection to the newborn baby as well as nutrients and growth factors.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> The makeup of the colostrum and the period of secretion varies from species to species.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>For humans, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> recommends exclusive breastfeeding for six months and breastfeeding in addition to other food for two years or more.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> In some cultures it is common to breastfeed children for three to five years, and the period may be even longer.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>Fresh goats milk is sometimes substituted for breast milk. This risks the child developing <a href="/wiki/Electrolyte" title="Electrolyte">electrolyte</a> imbalances, <a href="/wiki/Metabolic_acidosis" title="Metabolic acidosis">metabolic acidosis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Megaloblastic_anemia" title="Megaloblastic anemia">megaloblastic anemia</a>, and a host of <a href="/wiki/Allergic_reactions" title="Allergic reactions" class="mw-redirect">allergic reactions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_product_for_humans">Food product for humans</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Holstein_cows_large.jpg" title="File:Holstein cows large.jpg">File:Holstein cows large.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Holstein_cattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holstein cattle (page does not exist)">Holstein cattle</a>, the dominant breed in industrialized dairying today</div></div></div>
<p>In many cultures of the world, especially the Western world, humans continue to consume milk beyond infancy, using the milk of other animals (especially <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cattle (page does not exist)">cattle</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Goat (page does not exist)">goats</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sheep&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sheep (page does not exist)">sheep</a>) as a food product. Initially, the ability to digest milk was limited to children as adults did not produce <a href="/wiki/Lactase" title="Lactase">lactase</a>, an enzyme necessary for digesting the <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">lactose</a> in milk. Milk was therefore converted to <a href="/wiki/Curd" title="Curd">curd</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheese (page does not exist)">cheese</a> and other products to reduce the levels of lactose. Thousands of years ago, a chance mutation spread in human populations in Europe that enabled the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactase_persistence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactase persistence (page does not exist)">production of lactase in adulthood</a>. This allowed milk to be used as a new source of nutrition which could sustain populations when other food sources failed.<sup id="cite_ref-Nature_Milk_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nature_Milk-11">[11]</a></sup> Milk is processed into a variety of dairy products such as <a href="/wiki/Cream" title="Cream">cream</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butter" title="Butter">butter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kefir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kefir (page does not exist)">kefir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ice_cream" title="Ice cream">ice cream</a>, and cheese. Modern industrial processes use milk to produce <a href="/wiki/Casein" title="Casein">casein</a>, <a href="/wiki/Whey_protein" title="Whey protein">whey protein</a>, lactose, <a href="/wiki/Condensed_milk" title="Condensed milk">condensed milk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Powdered_milk" title="Powdered milk">powdered milk</a>, and many other food-additive and industrial products.
</p><p>The sugar lactose is found only in milk, <a href="/wiki/Forsythia" title="Forsythia">forsythia</a> flowers, and a few tropical shrubs. The enzyme needed to digest lactose, lactase, reaches its highest levels in the small intestines after birth and then begins a slow decline unless milk is consumed regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup> On the other hand, those groups who do continue to tolerate milk often have exercised great creativity in using the milk of <a href="/wiki/Domestication" title="Domestication">domesticated</a> <a href="/wiki/Ungulate" title="Ungulate">ungulates</a>, not only of cattle, but also sheep, goats, <a href="/wiki/Yak" title="Yak">yaks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo">water buffalo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reindeer" title="Reindeer">reindeers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Camel" title="Camel">camels</a>. The largest producer and consumer of cattle and buffalo milk in the world is <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="sortable wikitable" style="margin:auto">
<caption>Per capita consumption of cow's milk and cow's milk products in selected countries in 2005–2006<sup id="cite_ref-intro_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-intro-14">[14]</a></sup>

</td></tr>

<td> 12.2 </td>
<td> 3.3
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Terminology">Terminology</span></h2>
<p>The term <i>milk</i> is also used for white colored, non-animal beverages resembling milk in color and texture such as <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice_milk" title="Rice milk">rice milk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Almond_milk" title="Almond milk">almond milk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Coconut_milk" title="Coconut milk">coconut milk</a>. In addition, a substance secreted by <a href="/wiki/Columbidae" title="Columbidae">pigeons</a> to feed their young is called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crop_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crop milk (page does not exist)">crop milk</a> and bears some resemblance to mammalian milk.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dairy" class="extiw" title="wiktionary:dairy">Dairy</a> relates to milk and milk production, e.g. dairy products.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution_of_lactation">Evolution of lactation</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland">mammary gland</a> is thought to have been derived from apocrine skin glands.<sup id="cite_ref-Oftedal_2002_225.E2.80.93252_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oftedal_2002_225.E2.80.93252-16">[16]</a></sup> It has been suggested that the original function of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactation (page does not exist)">lactation</a> (milk production) was keeping eggs moist. Much of the argument is based on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Monotreme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Monotreme (page does not exist)">monotremes</a> (egg-laying mammals).<sup id="cite_ref-Oftedal_2002_225.E2.80.93252_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oftedal_2002_225.E2.80.93252-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> The original adaptive significance of milk secretions may have been nutrition<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> or immunological protection.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> This secretion gradually became more copious and accrued nutritional complexity over evolutionary time.<sup id="cite_ref-Oftedal_2002_225.E2.80.93252_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oftedal_2002_225.E2.80.93252-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-2004-0708-501,_Berlin,_Milch_von_Bolle_in_der_Pause.jpg" title="File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-2004-0708-501, Berlin, Milch von Bolle in der Pause.jpg">File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-2004-0708-501, Berlin, Milch von Bolle in der Pause.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Drinking milk in Germany in 1932</div></div></div>
<p>Humans first learned to regularly consume the milk of other mammals following the <a href="/wiki/Domestication" title="Domestication">domestication</a> of animals during the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution" title="Neolithic Revolution">Neolithic Revolution</a><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> or the development of <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>. This development occurred independently in several places around the world from as early as 9000–7000 BC in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southwest_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southwest Asia (page does not exist)">Southwest Asia</a><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> to 3500–3000 BC in the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> The most important dairy animals—cattle, sheep and goats—were first domesticated in Southwest Asia, although domestic cattle has been independently derived from wild <a href="/wiki/Aurochs" title="Aurochs">aurochs</a> populations several times since.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Initially animals were kept for meat, and archaeologist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Andrew_Sherratt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Andrew Sherratt (page does not exist)">Andrew Sherratt</a> has suggested that dairying, along with the exploitation of domestic animals for hair and labor, began much later in a separate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Secondary_products_revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Secondary products revolution (page does not exist)">secondary products revolution</a> in the 4th millennium BC.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> Sherratt's model is not supported by recent findings, based on the analysis of <a href="/wiki/Lipid" title="Lipid">lipid</a> residue in prehistoric pottery, that show that dairying was practiced in the early phases of agriculture in Southwest Asia, by at least the 7th millennium BC.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>From Southwest Asia domestic dairy animals spread to Europe (beginning around 7000 BC but not reaching Britain and Scandinavia until after 4000 BC),<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Asia (page does not exist)">South Asia</a> (7000–5500 BC).<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> The first farmers in central Europe<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> and Britain<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> milked their animals. <a href="/wiki/Pastoralism" title="Pastoralism">Pastoral</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nomadic_pastoralism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nomadic pastoralism (page does not exist)">pastoral nomadic</a> economies, which rely predominantly or exclusively on domestic animals and their products rather than crop farming, were developed as European farmers moved into the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pontic-Caspian_steppe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pontic-Caspian steppe (page does not exist)">Pontic-Caspian steppe</a> in the 4th millennium BC, and subsequently spread across much of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eurasian_steppe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eurasian steppe (page does not exist)">Eurasian steppe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> Sheep and goats were introduced to Africa from Southwest Asia, but African cattle may have been independently domesticated around 7000–6000 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Camels, domesticated in central Arabia in the 4th millennium BC, have also been used as a dairy animal in North Africa and the Arabian peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The earliest Egyptian records of burn treatment describe burn dressings using milk from mothers of male babies.<sup id="cite_ref-Pe.C4.87anac-_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pe.C4.87anac--37">[37]</a></sup> In the rest of the world (i.e., East and Southeast Asia, the Americas and Australia) milk and dairy products were historically not a large part of the diet, either because they remained populated by <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherers" title="Hunter-gatherers" class="mw-redirect">hunter-gatherers</a> who did not keep animals or the local agricultural economies did not include domesticated dairy species. Milk consumption became common in these regions comparatively recently, as a consequence of European <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonialism</a> and political domination over much of the world in the last 500 years.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, milk was called the virtuous white liquor because alcoholic beverages were more reliable than water.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industrialization">Industrialization</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SR_4409_6_Wheeled_Milk_Wagon_Didcot_Railway_Centre.jpg" title="File:SR 4409 6 Wheeled Milk Wagon Didcot Railway Centre.jpg">File:SR 4409 6 Wheeled Milk Wagon Didcot Railway Centre.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Preserved <a href="/w/index.php?title=Express_Dairies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Express Dairies (page does not exist)">Express Dairies</a> three-axle Milk Tank Wagon at the <a href="/wiki/Didcot_Railway_Centre" title="Didcot Railway Centre">Didcot Railway Centre</a>, based on an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southern_Railway_(Great_Britain)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southern Railway (Great Britain) (page does not exist)">SR</a> chassis</div></div></div>
<p>The growth in urban population coupled with the expansion of the railway network in the mid 19th century, brought about a revolution in milk production and supply. Individual railway firms began transporting milk from rural areas to London from the 1840s and 50s. Possibly the first such instance was in 1846, when <a href="/w/index.php?title=St_Thomas%E2%80%99s_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="St Thomas’s Hospital (page does not exist)">St Thomas’s Hospital</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a> contracted with milk suppliers outside London to provide milk by rail.<sup id="cite_ref-Atkins_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atkins-39">[39]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Great_Western_Railway" title="Great Western Railway">Great Western Railway</a> was an early and enthusiatic adopter, and began to transport milk into London from <a href="/wiki/Maidenhead" title="Maidenhead">Maidenhead</a> in 1860, despite much criticism. By 1900, the Company was transporting over 25 million gallons annually.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> The milk trade grew slowly through the 1860s, but went through a period of extensive, structural change in the 1870s and 80s.
</p><p>Urban demand began to grow, as consumer purchasing power increased and milk became regarded as a required daily commodity. Over the last three decades of the 19th century, demand for milk in most parts of the country doubled, or in some cases, tripled. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_Health_Acts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public Health Acts (page does not exist)">Legislation in 1875</a> made the adulteration of milk illegal - this combined with a marketing campaign to change the image of milk. The proportion of rural imports by rail as a percentage of total milk consumption in London grew from under 5% in the 1860s to over 96% by the early 20th century. By that point, the supply system for milk was the most highly organized and integrated of any food product.<sup id="cite_ref-Atkins_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atkins-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Milk_supply_1959_in_Oberlech,_Austria.jpg" title="File:Milk supply 1959 in Oberlech, Austria.jpg">File:Milk supply 1959 in Oberlech, Austria.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">1959 milk supply in Oberlech, Vorarlberg, Austria.</div></div></div>
<p>The first glass bottle packaging for milk was used in the 1870s. The first company to do so may have been the New York Dairy Company in 1877. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Express_Dairies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Express Dairies (page does not exist)">Express Dairy Company</a> in England began glass bottle production in 1880. In 1884, Hervey Thatcher, an American inventor from New York, invented a glass <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_bottle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk bottle (page does not exist)">milk bottle</a>, called 'Thatcher's Common Sense Milk Jar', which was sealed with a waxed paper disk.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_history_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk_history-41">[41]</a></sup> Later, in 1932, plastic-coated paper milk cartons were introduced commercially.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_history_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk_history-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1863, French chemist and biologist <a href="/wiki/Louis_Pasteur" title="Louis Pasteur">Louis Pasteur</a> invented pasteurization, a method of killing harmful bacteria in beverages and food products.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_history_41-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk_history-41">[41]</a></sup> He developed this method while on summer vacation in <a href="/wiki/Arbois" title="Arbois">Arbois</a>, to remedy the frequent acidity of the local <a href="/wiki/Wine" title="Wine">wines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VR1928_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VR1928-42">[42]</a></sup> He found out experimentally that it is sufficient to heat a young wine to only about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> for a brief time to kill the microbes, and that the wine could be nevertheless properly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aging_of_wine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aging of wine (page does not exist)">aged</a> without sacrificing the final quality.<sup id="cite_ref-VR1928_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VR1928-42">[42]</a></sup> In honor of Pasteur, the process became known as "pasteurization". Pasteurization was originally used as a way of preventing <a href="/wiki/Wine" title="Wine">wine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beer" title="Beer">beer</a> from souring.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Commercial pasteurizing equipment was produced in Germany in the 1880s, and the process had been adopted in <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stockholm" title="Stockholm">Stockholm</a> by 1885.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HwangHuang2009_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HwangHuang2009-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sources_of_milk">Sources of milk</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Farm_in_sogn_og_fjordane.JPG" title="File:Farm in sogn og fjordane.JPG">File:Farm in sogn og fjordane.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Modern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dairy_farm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dairy farm (page does not exist)">dairy farm</a> in Norway.</div></div></div>
<p>The females of all mammal species can by definition produce milk, but cow milk dominates commercial production. In 2011, FAO estimates 85% of all milk worldwide was produced from cows.<sup id="cite_ref-gs12_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gs12-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>Human milk is not produced or distributed industrially or commercially; however, milk banks exist that allow for the collection of donated human milk and its redistribution to infants who may benefit from human milk for various reasons (premature neonates, babies with allergies, <a href="/wiki/Inborn_error_of_metabolism" title="Inborn error of metabolism">metabolic diseases</a>, etc.).<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Western world, cow's milk is produced on an industrial scale and is by far the most commonly consumed form of milk. Commercial <a href="/wiki/Dairy_farming" title="Dairy farming" class="mw-redirect">dairy farming</a> using <a href="/w/index.php?title=Automatic_milking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Automatic milking (page does not exist)">automated milking</a> equipment produces the vast majority of milk in <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed countries</a>. <a href="/wiki/Dairy_cattle" title="Dairy cattle">Dairy cattle</a> such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holstein_cattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holstein cattle (page does not exist)">Holstein</a> have been bred selectively for increased milk production. About 90% of the dairy cows in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> and 85% in <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">Great Britain</a> are Holsteins.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup> Other dairy cows in the United States include <a href="/wiki/Ayrshire_cattle" title="Ayrshire cattle">Ayrshire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_Swiss" title="Brown Swiss">Brown Swiss</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guernsey_cattle" title="Guernsey cattle">Guernsey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jersey_cattle" title="Jersey cattle">Jersey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Milking_Shorthorn" title="Milking Shorthorn">Milking Shorthorn</a> (Dairy Shorthorn).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sources_aside_from_cows">Sources aside from cows</span></h3>
<div style="float:right;margin-left:1em;">
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Auto_images&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Auto images (page does not exist)">Template:Auto images</a>
</p>
</div>
<p>Aside from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cattle (page does not exist)">cattle</a>, many kinds of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Livestock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Livestock (page does not exist)">livestock</a> provide milk used by humans for dairy products. These animals include <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo#Dairy_products" title="Water buffalo">buffalo</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goat_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Goat milk (page does not exist)">goat</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sheep_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sheep milk (page does not exist)">sheep</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Camel_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Camel milk (page does not exist)">camel</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ass%27s_milk_(Donkey%27s_milk)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ass's milk (Donkey's milk) (page does not exist)">donkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Horse#Products" title="Horse">horse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reindeer" title="Reindeer">reindeer</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pack_yak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pack yak (page does not exist)">yak</a>. The first four respectively produced about 11%, 2%, 1.4% and 0.2% of all milk worldwide in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-gs12_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gs12-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>, small <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moose_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moose milk (page does not exist)">moose dairies</a> also exist.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the US National Bison Association, <a href="/wiki/American_bison" title="American bison">American bison</a> (also called American buffalo) are not milked commercially;<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> however, various sources report cows resulting from cross-breeding bison and domestic cattle are good milk producers, and have been used both during the European settlement of North America<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> and during the development of commercial <a href="/wiki/Beefalo" title="Beefalo">Beefalo</a> in the 1970s and 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production_worldwide">Production worldwide</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Milk_production_and_consumption.svg" title="File:Milk production and consumption.svg">File:Milk production and consumption.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Citation_needed_span&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Citation needed span (page does not exist)">Template:Citation needed span</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:left;margin:1.2em">
<caption>Top ten cow milk producers in 2010<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</caption>
<tr>
<th>Country </th>
<th>Production<br />(<a href="/wiki/Tonne" title="Tonne">tonnes</a>)
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_US&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data US (page does not exist)">Template:Country data US</a> </td>
<td> 87,446,130
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data India (page does not exist)">Template:Country data India</a> </td>
<td> 50,300,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data China (page does not exist)">Template:Country data China</a> </td>
<td> 36,036,086
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Russia (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Russia</a> </td>
<td> 31,895,100
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Brazil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Brazil (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Brazil</a> </td>
<td> 31,667,600
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Germany (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Germany</a> </td>
<td> 29,628,900
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data France (page does not exist)">Template:Country data France</a> </td>
<td> 23,301,200
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data New Zealand (page does not exist)">Template:Country data New Zealand</a> </td>
<td> 17,010,500
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Template:Country data United Kingdom</a> </td>
<td> 13,960,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Turkey (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Turkey</a> </td>
<td> 12,480,100
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>World</td>
<td> 599,438,003
</td></tr></table>
<p>In 2010, the largest producer of milk and milk products was India followed by the United States, China, Germany, Brazil, and Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-Blasko_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blasko-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> All European Union members together produced about 138 million tonnes of milk in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MilkMaid.JPG" title="File:MilkMaid.JPG">File:MilkMaid.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Girl milking a cow by hand</div></div></div>
<p>Increasing affluence in <a href="/wiki/Developing_countries" title="Developing countries" class="mw-redirect">developing countries</a>, as well as increased promotion of milk and milk products, has led to a rise in milk consumption in developing countries in recent years. In turn, the opportunities presented by these growing markets have attracted investment by <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational</a> dairy firms. Nevertheless, in many countries production remains on a small scale and presents significant opportunities for diversification of income sources by small farmers.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Local milk collection centers, where milk is collected and chilled prior to being transferred to urban dairies, are a good example of where farmers have been able to work on a <a href="/wiki/Cooperative" title="Cooperative">cooperative</a> basis, particularly in countries such as <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Production_yields">Production yields</span></h3>
<p>FAO reports<sup id="cite_ref-gs12_46-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gs12-46">[46]</a></sup> Israel dairy farms are the most productive in the world, with an yield of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> milk per cow per year. This survey over 2001 and 2007 was conducted by ICAR (International Committee for Animal Recording<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>) across 17 developed countries. The survey found that the average herd size in these developed countries increased from 74 to 99 cows per herd between 2001 to 2007. A dairy farm had an average of 19 cows per herd in Norway, and 337 in New Zealand. Annual milk production in the same period increased from 7,726 to 8,550&#160;kg per cow in these developed countries. The lowest average production was in New Zealand at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> per cow. The milk yield per cow depended on production systems, nutrition of the cows, and only to a minor extent different genetic potential of the animals. What the cow ate made the most impact on the production obtained. New Zealand cows with the lowest yield per year grazed all year, in contrast to Israel with the highest yield where the cows ate in barns with energy-rich mixed diet.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right;">
<caption>Top ten buffalo milk producers in 2010<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</caption>
<tr>
<th>Country </th>
<th>Production<br />(<a href="/wiki/Tonne" title="Tonne">tonnes</a>)
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data India (page does not exist)">Template:Country data India</a> </td>
<td> 62,400,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Pakistan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Pakistan (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Pakistan</a> </td>
<td> 22,279,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data China (page does not exist)">Template:Country data China</a> </td>
<td> 3,100,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Egypt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Egypt (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Egypt</a> </td>
<td> 2,725,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Nepal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Nepal (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Nepal</a> </td>
<td> 1,066,870
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Iran&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Iran (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Iran</a> </td>
<td> 279,800
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Myanmar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Myanmar (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Myanmar</a> </td>
<td> 248,400
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Italy (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Italy</a> </td>
<td> 210,200
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Sri_Lanka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Sri Lanka (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Sri Lanka</a> </td>
<td> 46,990
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Bangladesh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Bangladesh (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Bangladesh</a> </td>
<td> 36,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>World</td>
<td> 92,517,217
</td></tr></table>
<p>The milk yield per cow in the United States, the world's largest cow milk producer, was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> per year in 2010. In contrast, the milk yields per cow in India and China – the second and third largest producers – were respectively <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> per year.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Price">Price</span></h3>
<p>It was reported in 2007 that with increased worldwide prosperity and the competition of bio-fuel production for feed stocks, both the demand for and the price of milk had substantially increased worldwide. Particularly notable was the rapid increase of consumption of milk in China and the rise of the price of milk in the United States above the government subsidized price.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> In 2010 the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">Department of Agriculture</a> predicted farmers would receive an average of $1.35 per US gallon of cow's milk (35 cents per liter), which is down 30 cents per gallon from 2007 and below the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Break-even&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Break-even (page does not exist)">break-even</a> point for many cattle farmers.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Grading">Grading</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In the United States, there are two grades of milk, with Grade A primarily used for direct sales and consumption in stores, and Grade B used for indirect consumption, such as in cheese making or other processing.
</p><p>The differences between the two grades are defined in the Wisconsin administrative code for Agriculture, Trade, and Consumer Protection, chapter 60.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Grade B generally refers to milk that is cooled in milk cans, which are immersed in a bath of cold flowing water that typically is drawn up from an underground water well rather than using mechanical refrigeration.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Physical_and_chemical_properties_of_milk">Physical and chemical properties of milk</span></h2>
<p>Milk is an <a href="/wiki/Emulsion" title="Emulsion">emulsion</a> or <a href="/wiki/Colloid" title="Colloid">colloid</a> of <a href="/wiki/Butterfat" title="Butterfat">butterfat</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Globules_of_fat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Globules of fat (page does not exist)">globules</a> within a water-based fluid that contains dissolved carbohydrates and protein aggregates with minerals.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> Because it is produced as a food source for a neonate, all of its contents provide benefits to the growing young. The principal requirements of the neonate are energy (lipids, lactose, and protein), biosynthesis of non-essential amino acids supplied by proteins (essential amino acids and amino groups), essential fatty acids, vitamins and inorganic elements, and water.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl>
<dd><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TriglycerideDairyButter.png" title="File:TriglycerideDairyButter.png">File:TriglycerideDairyButter.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Butterfat is a <a href="/wiki/Triglyceride" title="Triglyceride">triglyceride</a> (fat) derived from fatty acids such as <a href="/wiki/Myristic_acid" title="Myristic acid">myristic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palmitic_acid" title="Palmitic acid">palmitic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Oleic_acid" title="Oleic acid">oleic acids</a>.</div></div></div>
</dd>
</dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lipids">Lipids</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Initially milk fat is secreted in the form of a fat globule surrounded by a membrane.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1995_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1995-65">[65]</a></sup> Each fat globule is composed almost entirely of triacylglycerols and is surrounded by a membrane consisting of complex lipids such as <a href="/wiki/Phospholipid" title="Phospholipid">phospholipids</a>, along with proteins. These act as <a href="/wiki/Emulsifier" title="Emulsifier" class="mw-redirect">emulsifiers</a> which keep the individual globules from coalescing and protect the contents of these globules from various <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzymes</a> in the fluid portion of the milk. Although 97–98% of lipids are triacylglycrols, small amounts of di- and monoacylglycerols, free cholesterol and cholesterol esters, free fatty acids, and phospholipids are also present. Unlike protein and carbohydrates, fat composition in milk varies widely in the composition due to genetic, lactational, and nutritional factor difference between different species.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1995_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1995-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Like composition, fat globules vary in size from less than 0.2 to about 15 micrometers in diameter between different species. Diameter may also vary between animals within a species and at different times within a milking of a single animal. In unhomogenized cow's milk, the fat globules have an average diameter of two to four <a href="/wiki/Micrometre" title="Micrometre">micrometers</a> and with homogenization, average around 0.4 micrometers.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1995_65-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1995-65">[65]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fat-soluble&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fat-soluble (page does not exist)">fat-soluble</a> vitamins <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_A" title="Vitamin A">A</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin D (page does not exist)">D</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_E" title="Vitamin E">E</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_K" title="Vitamin K">K</a> along with essential fatty acids such as linoleic and linolenic acid are found within the milk fat portion of the milk.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Proteins">Proteins</span></h3>
<p>Normal bovine milk contains 30–35&#160;grams of protein per liter of which about 80% is arranged in casein micelles.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Caseins">Caseins</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The largest structures in the fluid portion of the milk are <a href="/wiki/Casein" title="Casein">"casein micelles"</a>: aggregates of several thousand protein molecules with superficial resemblance to a surfactant <a href="/wiki/Micelle" title="Micelle">micelle</a>, bonded with the help of nanometer-scale particles of <a href="/wiki/Calcium_phosphate" title="Calcium phosphate">calcium phosphate</a>. Each casein micelle is roughly spherical and about a tenth of a micrometer across. There are four different types of casein proteins: αs1-, αs2-, β-, and κ-caseins. Collectively, they make up around 76–86%<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-64">[64]</a></sup> of the protein in milk, by weight. Most of the casein proteins are bound into the micelles. There are several competing theories regarding the precise structure of the micelles, but they share one important feature: the outermost layer consists of strands of one type of protein, <a href="/w/index.php?title=K-casein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="K-casein (page does not exist)">k-casein</a>, reaching out from the body of the micelle into the surrounding fluid. These kappa-casein molecules all have a negative <a href="/wiki/Electrical_charge" title="Electrical charge" class="mw-redirect">electrical charge</a> and therefore repel each other, keeping the micelles separated under normal conditions and in a stable <a href="/wiki/Colloid" title="Colloid">colloidal</a> <a href="/wiki/Suspension_(chemistry)" title="Suspension (chemistry)">suspension</a> in the water-based surrounding fluid.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-chem_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chem-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>Milk contains dozens of other types of proteins beside the caseins including enzymes. These other proteins are more water-soluble than the caseins and do not form larger structures. Because the proteins remain suspended in the <a href="/wiki/Whey" title="Whey">whey</a> left behind when the caseins coagulate into curds, they are collectively known as <i>whey proteins</i>. Whey proteins make up approximately 20% of the protein in milk, by weight. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactoglobulin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactoglobulin (page does not exist)">Lactoglobulin</a> is the most common whey protein by a large margin.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Salts.2C_minerals.2C_and_vitamins">Salts, minerals, and vitamins</span></h3>
<p>Minerals or milk salts, are traditional names for a variety of cations and anions within bovine milk. Calcium, phosphate, magnesium, sodium, potassium, citrate, and chlorine are all included as minerals and they typically occur at concentration of 5–40 mM. The milk salts strongly interact with casein, most notably calcium phosphate. It is present in excess and often, much greater excess of solubility of solid calcium phosphate.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_64-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-64">[64]</a></sup> In addition to calcium, milk is a good source of many other vitamins. Vitamins A, B6, B12, C, D, K, E, thiamine, niacin, biotin, riboflavin, folates, and pantothenic acid are all present in milk.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Calcium_phosphate_structure">Calcium phosphate structure</span></h4>
<p>For many years the most accepted theory of the structure of a micelle was that it was composed of spherical casein aggregates, called submicelles, that were held together by calcium phosphate linkages. However, there are two recent models of the casein micelle that refute the distinct micellular structures within the micelle.
</p><p>The first theory attributed to de Kruif and Holt, proposes that nanoclusters of calcium phosphate and the phosphopeptide fraction of beta-casein are the centerpiece to micellular structure. Specifically in this view, unstructured proteins organize around the calcium phosphate giving rise to their structure and thus no specific structure is formed.
</p><p>The second theory proposed by Horne, the growth of calcium phosphate nanoclusters begins the process of micelle formation but is limited by binding phosphopeptide loop regions of the caseins. Once bound, protein-protein interactions are formed and polymerization occurs, in which K-casein is used as an end cap, to form micelles with trapped calcium phosphate nanoclusters.
</p><p>Some sources indicate that the trapped calcium phosphate is in the form of Ca9(PO4)6;
whereas, others say it is similar to the structure of the mineral brushite CaHPO4 -2H2O.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Carbohydrates_and_miscellaneous_contents">Carbohydrates and miscellaneous contents</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hydrolysis_of_lactose.svg" title="File:Hydrolysis of lactose.svg">File:Hydrolysis of lactose.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A simplified representation of a <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">lactose</a> molecule being broken down into <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> (2) and <a href="/wiki/Galactose" title="Galactose">galactose</a> (1)</div></div></div>
<p>Milk contains several different <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrate</a> including lactose, glucose, galactose, and other oligosaccharides. The <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">lactose</a> gives milk its sweet taste and contributes approximately 40% of whole cow's milk's calories. Lactose is a disaccharide composite of two <a href="/wiki/Monosaccharide" title="Monosaccharide">simple sugars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Galactose" title="Galactose">galactose</a>. Bovine milk averages 4.8% anhydrous lactose, which amounts to about 50% of the total solids of skimmed milk. Levels of lactose are dependant upon the type of milk as other carbohydrates can be present at higher concentrations that lactose in milks.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_64-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other components found in raw cow's milk are living <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_blood_cell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White blood cell (page does not exist)">white blood cells</a>, mammary gland cells, various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacteria</a>, and a large number of active <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzymes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Appearance">Appearance</span></h3>
<p>Both the fat globules and the smaller casein micelles, which are just large enough to deflect light, contribute to the opaque white color of milk. The fat globules contain some yellow-orange carotene, enough in some breeds (such as <a href="/wiki/Guernsey_cattle" title="Guernsey cattle">Guernsey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jersey_cattle" title="Jersey cattle">Jersey cattle</a>) to impart a golden or "creamy" hue to a glass of milk. The <a href="/wiki/Riboflavin" title="Riboflavin">riboflavin</a> in the whey portion of milk has a greenish color, which sometimes can be discerned in skimmed milk or whey products.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup> Fat-free skimmed milk has only the casein micelles to scatter light, and they tend to scatter shorter-wavelength blue light more than they do red, giving skimmed milk a bluish tint.<sup id="cite_ref-chem_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chem-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Processing">Processing</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Milkproducts_v2.svg" title="File:Milkproducts v2.svg">File:Milkproducts v2.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Milk products and productions relationships (Click for details)</div></div></div>
<p>In most <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_world&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western world (page does not exist)">Western</a> countries, centralized <a href="/wiki/Dairy" title="Dairy">dairy</a> facilities process milk and products obtained from milk (<a href="/wiki/Dairy_product" title="Dairy product">dairy products</a>), such as <a href="/wiki/Cream" title="Cream">cream</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butter" title="Butter">butter</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheese (page does not exist)">cheese</a>. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">US</a>, these dairies usually are local companies, while in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a> facilities may be run by very large nationwide or trans-national corporations (such as <a href="/wiki/Fonterra" title="Fonterra">Fonterra</a>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pasteurization">Pasteurization</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pasteurization" title="Pasteurization">Pasteurization</a> is used to kill harmful <a href="/wiki/Microorganism" title="Microorganism">microorganisms</a> by heating the milk for a short time and then immediately cooling it. The standard High Temperature Short Time (HTST) process produces a 99.999% reduction in the number of bacteria in milk, rendering it safe to drink for up to three weeks if continually refrigerated. Dairies print <a href="/wiki/Shelf_life" title="Shelf life">expiration dates</a> on each container, after which stores will remove any unsold milk from their shelves.
</p><p>A side effect of the heating of pasteurization is that some vitamin and mineral content is lost. Soluble calcium and phosphorus decrease by 5%, thiamin and vitamin B12 by 10%, and vitamin C by 20%.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Because losses are small in comparison to the large amount of the two B-vitamins present, milk continues to provide significant amounts of thiamin and vitamin B12. The loss of vitamin C is not nutritionally signifigant, as milk is not an important dietary source of vitamin C.
</p><p>A newer process, ultrapasteurization or ultra-high temperature treatment (<a href="/wiki/Ultra-high-temperature_processing" title="Ultra-high-temperature processing">UHT</a>), heats the milk to a higher temperature for a shorter amount of time. This extends its <a href="/wiki/Shelf_life" title="Shelf life">shelf life</a> and allows the milk to be stored unrefrigerated because of the longer lasting <a href="/wiki/Sterilization_(microbiology)" title="Sterilization (microbiology)">sterilization</a> effect.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Microfiltration">Microfiltration</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Microfiltration" title="Microfiltration">Microfiltration</a> is a process that partially replaces pasteurization and produces milk with fewer microorganisms and longer shelf life without a change in the taste of the milk. In this process, cream is separated from the whey and is pasteurized in the usual way, but the whey is forced through ceramic microfilters that trap 99.9% of microorganisms in the milk{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} (as compared to 99.999% killing of microorganisms in standard <a href="/wiki/Flash_pasteurization" title="Flash pasteurization">HTST pasteurization</a>). The whey then is recombined with the pasteurized cream to reconstitute the original milk composition.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Creaming_and_homogenization">Creaming and homogenization</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cow_milking_machine_in_action_DSC04132.jpg" title="File:Cow milking machine in action DSC04132.jpg">File:Cow milking machine in action DSC04132.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A milking machine in action</div></div></div>
<p>Upon standing for 12 to 24 hours, fresh milk has a tendency to separate into a high-fat <a href="/wiki/Cream" title="Cream">cream</a> layer on top of a larger, low-fat milk layer. The cream often is sold as a separate product with its own uses. Today the separation of the cream from the milk usually is accomplished rapidly in <a href="/wiki/Centrifuge" title="Centrifuge">centrifugal</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cream_separator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cream separator (page does not exist)">cream separators</a>. The fat globules rise to the top of a container of milk because fat is less dense than water. The smaller the globules, the more other molecular-level forces prevent this from happening. In fact, the cream rises in cow's milk much more quickly than a simple model would predict: rather than isolated globules, the fat in the milk tends to form into clusters containing about a million globules, held together by a number of minor whey proteins.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup> These clusters rise faster than individual globules can. The fat globules in milk from goats, sheep, and water buffalo do not form clusters as readily and are smaller to begin with, resulting in a slower separation of cream from these milks.
</p><p>Milk often is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Homogenization_(chemistry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homogenization (chemistry) (page does not exist)">homogenized</a>, a treatment that prevents a cream layer from separating out of the milk. The milk is pumped at high pressures through very narrow tubes, breaking up the fat globules through <a href="/wiki/Turbulence" title="Turbulence">turbulence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cavitation" title="Cavitation">cavitation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> A greater number of smaller particles possess more total <a href="/wiki/Surface_area" title="Surface area">surface area</a> than a smaller number of larger ones, and the original fat globule membranes cannot completely cover them. Casein micelles are attracted to the newly exposed fat surfaces. Nearly one-third of the micelles in the milk end up participating in this new membrane structure. The casein weighs down the globules and interferes with the clustering that accelerated separation. The exposed fat globules are vulnerable to certain <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzymes</a> present in milk, which could break down the fats and produce <a href="/wiki/Rancidification" title="Rancidification">rancid</a> flavors. To prevent this, the enzymes are inactivated by pasteurizing the milk immediately before or during homogenization.
</p><p>Homogenized milk tastes blander but feels creamier in the mouth than unhomogenized. It is whiter and more resistant to developing off flavors.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup> Creamline (or cream-top) milk is unhomogenized. It may or may not have been pasteurized. Milk that has undergone high-pressure homogenization, sometimes labeled as "ultra-homogenized," has a longer shelf life than milk that has undergone ordinary homogenization at lower pressures.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Homogenized milk may be more digestible than unhomogenized milk.<sup id="cite_ref-MichalskiJanuel_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MichalskiJanuel-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kurt A. Oster, M.D., who worked during the 1960s through the 1980s, suggested a link between homogenized milk and <a href="/wiki/Atherosclerosis" title="Atherosclerosis">atherosclerosis</a>, due to damage to <a href="/wiki/Plasmalogen" title="Plasmalogen">plasmalogen</a> resulting from the release of bovine <a href="/wiki/Xanthine_oxidase" title="Xanthine oxidase">xanthine oxidase</a> (BXO) from the milk fat globular membrane (MFGM) during homogenization. Oster's hypothesis has been widely criticized, however, and has not been generally accepted by the scientific community. No link has been found between atherosclerosis and milk consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-MichalskiJanuel_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MichalskiJanuel-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition_and_health">Nutrition and health</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The composition of milk differs widely among species. Factors such as the type of protein; the proportion of protein, fat, and sugar; the levels of various vitamins and minerals; and the size of the <a href="/wiki/Butterfat" title="Butterfat">butterfat</a> <a href="/wiki/Drop_(liquid)" title="Drop (liquid)">globules</a>, and the strength of the <a href="/wiki/Curd" title="Curd">curd</a> are among those that may vary.<sup id="cite_ref-intro_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-intro-14">[14]</a></sup> For example:
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Breast_milk" title="Breast milk">Human milk</a> contains, on average, 1.1% protein, 4.2% fat, 7.0% lactose (a sugar), and supplies 72 kcal of energy per 100 <a href="/wiki/Gram" title="Gram">grams</a>.
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cow (page does not exist)">Cow</a> milk contains, on average, 3.4% protein, 3.6% fat, and 4.6% lactose, 0.7% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dietary_mineral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dietary mineral (page does not exist)">minerals</a><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> and supplies 66&#160;kcal of energy per 100&#160;grams. See also <a href="/wiki/Milk#Nutritional_value" title="Milk">Nutritional value</a> further on.
</li>
</ul>
<p>Donkey and horse milk have the lowest fat content, while the milk of <a href="/wiki/Pinniped" title="Pinniped">seals</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whale" title="Whale">whales</a> may contain more than 50% fat.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<caption> Milk composition analysis, per 100&#160;grams<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</caption>
<tr>
<th> Constituents
</th>
<th> Unit
</th>
