</td></tr></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cow.27s_milk">Cow's milk</span></h3>
<p>These compositions vary by breed, animal, and point in the lactation period.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<caption>Milk fat percentages
</caption>
<tr>
<th>Cow breed
</th>
<th>Approximate percentage
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Jersey_cattle" title="Jersey cattle">Jersey</a>
</td>
<td>5.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Zebu" title="Zebu">Zebu</a>
</td>
<td>4.7
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Brown_Swiss" title="Brown Swiss">Brown Swiss</a>
</td>
<td>4.0
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Holstein_cattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holstein cattle (page does not exist)">Holstein-Friesian</a>
</td>
<td>3.6
</td></tr></table>
<p>The protein range for these four breeds is 3.3% to 3.9%, while the lactose range is 4.7% to 4.9%.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Food_and_Cooking_12-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Food_and_Cooking-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>Milk fat percentages may be manipulated by dairy farmers' stock diet formulation strategies. Mastitis infection can cause fat levels to decline.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutritional_value">Nutritional value</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
</p><p>Processed cow's milk was formulated to contain differing amounts of fat during the 1950s. One cup (250&#160;ml) of 2%-fat cow's milk contains 285&#160;mg of <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a>, which represents 22% to 29% of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daily_recommended_intake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daily recommended intake (page does not exist)">daily recommended intake</a> (DRI) of calcium for an adult. Depending on the age, milk contains 8&#160;<a href="/wiki/Gram" title="Gram">grams</a> of <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">protein</a>, and a number of other nutrients (either naturally or through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_fortification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food fortification (page does not exist)">fortification</a>) including:
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Biotin" title="Biotin">Biotin</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Iodine" title="Iodine">Iodine</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">Magnesium</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pantothenic_acid" title="Pantothenic acid">Pantothenic acid</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Potassium" title="Potassium">Potassium</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Riboflavin" title="Riboflavin">Riboflavin</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Selenium" title="Selenium">Selenium</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Thiamine" title="Thiamine">Thiamine</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vitamin_A" title="Vitamin A">Vitamin A</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B12&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B12 (page does not exist)">Vitamin B<sub>12</sub></a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin D (page does not exist)">Vitamins D</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vitamin_K" title="Vitamin K">Vitamin K</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The amount of <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a> from milk that is absorbed by the human body is disputed.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> Calcium from dairy products has a greater <a href="/wiki/Bioavailability" title="Bioavailability">bioavailability</a> than calcium from certain vegetables, such as <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a>, that contain high levels of calcium-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Chelating&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chelating (page does not exist)">chelating</a> agents,<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> but a similar or lesser bioavailability than calcium from low-oxalate vegetables such as kale, broccoli, or other vegetables in the <i>Brassica</i> genus.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Recommended_consumption">Recommended consumption</span></h3>
<p>The U.S. federal government document <i>Dietary Guidelines for Americans, 2010</i><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> recommends consumption of 3 glasses of fat-free or low-fat milk for adults and children 9 and older (less for younger children).  This recommendation is disputed by some health researchers who call for more study of the issue,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> given that there are other sources for calcium and vitamin D.  The researchers also claim that the recommendations have been unduly influenced by the American dairy industry, and that whole milk may be better for health due to its increased ability to satiate hunger.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medical_research">Medical research</span></h3>
<p>A 2006 study found that for women desiring to have a child, those who consume full fat dairy products may slightly increase their fertility, while those consuming low-fat dairy products may slightly reduce their fertility.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous studies have found that <a href="/wiki/Conjugated_linoleic_acid" title="Conjugated linoleic acid">conjugated linoleic acid</a>, found mainly in milk, meat and dairy products, provides several health benefits including prevention of atherosclerosis, different types of cancer, and hypertension and improved immune function.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated459_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated459-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated459_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated459-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is recent evidence suggesting consumption of milk is effective at promoting muscle growth<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> and improving post exercise muscle recovery.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, scientists at the <a href="/wiki/Harvard_School_of_Public_Health" title="Harvard School of Public Health">Harvard School of Public Health</a> identified a substance in dairy fat, trans-palmitoleic acid, that may substantially reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes. The researchers examined participants who have been followed for 20 years in an observational study to evaluate risk factors for cardiovascular diseases in older adults. During followup it was found that individuals with higher circulating levels of trans-palmitoleic acid had a much lower risk of developing diabetes, with about a 60% lower risk among participants in the highest quintile (fifth) of trans-palmitoleic acid levels.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lactose_intolerance">Lactose intolerance</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">Lactose</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Disaccharide" title="Disaccharide">disaccharide</a> sugar component of all milk, must be cleaved in the small intestine by the <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzyme</a> <a href="/wiki/Lactase" title="Lactase">lactase</a> in order for its constituents, <a href="/wiki/Galactose" title="Galactose">galactose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a>, to be absorbed. The production of the enzyme lactase declines significantly after <a href="/wiki/Weaning" title="Weaning">weaning</a> in all mammals. Consequently, many humans become unable to digest lactose properly as they mature. There is a great deal of variance, with some individuals reacting badly to even small amounts of lactose, some able to consume moderate quantities, and some able to consume large quantities of milk and other dairy products without problems. The gene in humans that controls lactase production, and hence lactose tolerance/intolerance, is labeled C/T-13910.<sup id="cite_ref-Babu.2C_J._2009_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Babu.2C_J._2009-90">[90]</a></sup> An individual who consumes milk without producing sufficient lactase may suffer <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrhea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flatulence" title="Flatulence">intestinal gas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cramp" title="Cramp">cramps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bloating" title="Bloating">bloating</a>, as the undigested lactose travels through the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gastrointestinal_tract&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gastrointestinal tract (page does not exist)">gastrointestinal tract</a> and serves as nourishment for intestinal <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microflora&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microflora (page does not exist)">microflora</a> that <a href="/w/index.php?title=Excrete&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Excrete (page does not exist)">excretes</a> gas in processes known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(biochemistry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (biochemistry) (page does not exist)">fermentation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anaerobic_respiration" title="Anaerobic respiration">anaerobic respiration</a>.
</p><p>It is estimated that 30 to 50 million Americans are lactose intolerant, including 75% of Native Americans and African Americans, and 90% of Asian Americans. Lactose intolerance is less common among those descended from northern Europeans.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> Other genetic groups that have a lower prevalence of lactose intolerance are the <a href="/wiki/Tuareg_people" title="Tuareg people">Tuareg</a> of the Sahara, the <a href="/wiki/Fula_people" title="Fula people">Fulani</a> of the West African Sahel, and the <a href="/wiki/Beja_people" title="Beja people">Beja</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kabbabish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kabbabish (page does not exist)">Kabbabish</a> of Sudan, as well as possibly the <a href="/wiki/Tutsi" title="Tutsi">Tutsi</a> population of the Uganda–Rwanda area.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Another locus of lactose tolerance is in Northern India.<sup id="cite_ref-Babu.2C_J._2009_90-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Babu.2C_J._2009-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lactose intolerance is a natural process and there is no reliable way to prevent or reverse it.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Possible_harms">Possible harms</span></h3>
<p>Some studies suggest that milk consumption may increase the risk of suffering from certain health problems. Cow <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_allergy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk allergy (page does not exist)">milk allergy</a> (CMA) is an immunologically mediated adverse reaction to one or more cow's milk proteins. Rarely is it severe enough to cause death.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Milk contains <a href="/wiki/Casein" title="Casein">casein</a>, a substance that breaks down in the human stomach to produce <a href="/wiki/Casomorphin" title="Casomorphin">casomorphin</a>, an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opioid_peptide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opioid peptide (page does not exist)">opioid peptide</a>. In the early 1990s it was hypothesized that casomorphin can cause or aggravate <a href="/wiki/Autism_spectrum_disorder" title="Autism spectrum disorder" class="mw-redirect">autism spectrum disorders</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-95">[95]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Gluten-free,_casein-free_diet" title="Gluten-free, casein-free diet">casein-free diets</a> are widely promoted. Studies supporting these claims have had significant flaws, and the data are inadequate to guide autism treatment recommendations.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>A study demonstrated that men who drink a large amount of milk and consume dairy products were at a slightly increased risk of developing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parkinson%27s_disease&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parkinson's disease (page does not exist)">Parkinson's disease</a>; the effect for women was smaller.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-96">[96]</a></sup> The reason behind this is not fully understood, and it also remains unclear why there is less of a risk for women.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-96">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> Several sources suggest a correlation between high calcium intake (2000&#160;mg per day, or twice the US <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recommended_daily_allowance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recommended daily allowance (page does not exist)">recommended daily allowance</a>, equivalent to six or more glasses of milk per day) and <a href="/wiki/Prostate_cancer" title="Prostate cancer">prostate cancer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> A large study specifically implicates dairy, i.e. low-fat milk and other dairy to which <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_A_palmitate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin A palmitate (page does not exist)">vitamin A palmitate</a> has been added.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>A review published by the <a href="/wiki/World_Cancer_Research_Fund" title="World Cancer Research Fund">World Cancer Research Fund</a> and the <a href="/wiki/American_Institute_for_Cancer_Research" title="American Institute for Cancer Research">American Institute for Cancer Research</a> states that at least eleven human population studies have linked excessive dairy product consumption and prostate cancer.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>Medical studies also have shown a possible link between milk consumption and the exacerbation of diseases such as <a href="/wiki/Crohn%27s_disease" title="Crohn's disease">Crohn's disease</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hirschsprung%27s_disease" title="Hirschsprung's disease">Hirschsprung's disease</a>–mimicking symptoms in babies with existing cow's milk allergies,<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> and the aggravation of Behçet's disease.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flavored_milk_in_US_schools">Flavored milk in US schools</span></h3>
<p>Milk must be offered at every meal if a <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> school district wishes to get reimbursement from the federal government.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} A quarter of the largest school districts in the US offer rice or soy milk and almost 17% of all US school districts offer lactose-free milk. Seventy-one percent of the milk served in US school cafeterias is flavored, causing some school districts to propose a ban because flavored milk has added sugars. (Though some flavored milk products use artificial sweeteners instead.)  The Boulder, Colorado school district banned flavored milk in 2009 and instead installed a dispenser that keeps the milk colder.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bovine_growth_hormone_supplementation">Bovine growth hormone supplementation</span></h2>
<p>Since November 1993, with FDA approval,<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Monsanto" title="Monsanto">Monsanto</a> has been selling <a href="/wiki/Bovine_somatotropin" title="Bovine somatotropin">recombinant bovine somatotropin (rbST)</a>, also called rBGH, to dairy farmers. Cows produce bovine growth hormone naturally, but some producers administer an additional recombinant version of BGH which is produced through a <a href="/wiki/Genetically_engineered" title="Genetically engineered" class="mw-redirect">genetically engineered</a> <a href="/wiki/Escherichia_coli" title="Escherichia coli">E. coli</a> because it increases milk production. Bovine growth hormone also stimulates liver production of <a href="/wiki/Insulin-like_growth_factor_1" title="Insulin-like growth factor 1">insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF1)</a>. Monsanto has stated that both of these compounds are harmless given the levels found in milk and the effects of <a href="/wiki/Pasteurization" title="Pasteurization">pasteurization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IFST_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IFST-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>On June 9, 2006, the largest milk processor in the world and the two largest <a href="/wiki/Supermarket" title="Supermarket">supermarkets</a> in the United States – <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dean_Foods&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dean Foods (page does not exist)">Dean Foods</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wal-Mart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wal-Mart (page does not exist)">Wal-Mart</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kroger" title="Kroger">Kroger</a> – announced that they are "on a nationwide search for rBGH-free milk."<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> Milk from cows given rBST may be sold in the United States, and the FDA stated that no significant difference has been shown between milk derived from rBST-treated and that from non-rBST-treated cows.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> Milk that advertises that it comes from cows not treated with rBST, is required to state this finding on its label.
</p><p>Cows receiving rBGH supplements may more frequently contract an udder infection known as <a href="/wiki/Mastitis" title="Mastitis">mastitis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Problems with mastitis have led to Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and Japan banning milk from rBST treated cows. Mastitis, among other diseases, may be responsible for the fact that levels of <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_blood_cell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White blood cell (page does not exist)">white blood cells</a> in milk vary naturally.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-112">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>rBGH is also banned in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism">Criticism</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegan (page does not exist)">Vegans</a> and some other <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian" title="Vegetarian" class="mw-redirect">vegetarians</a> do not consume milk for reasons mostly related to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal rights (page does not exist)">animal rights</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental vegetarianism (page does not exist)">environmental concerns</a>. They may object to features of <a href="/wiki/Dairy_farming" title="Dairy farming" class="mw-redirect">dairy farming</a> including the necessity of keeping dairy cows pregnant, the killing of almost all the male offspring of dairy cows (either by disposal soon after birth, for <a href="/wiki/Veal" title="Veal">veal</a> production, or for <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>), the routine separation of mother and calf soon after birth, other perceived <a href="/wiki/Cruelty_to_animals" title="Cruelty to animals">inhumane treatment</a> of <a href="/wiki/Dairy_cattle" title="Dairy cattle">dairy cattle</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_slaughter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal slaughter (page does not exist)">culling</a> of cows after their productive lives.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some have criticized the American government's promotion of milk consumption. The United States government administers the popular <a href="/wiki/Got_Milk%3F" title="Got Milk?">Got Milk?</a> and milk mustache advertising campaigns, which cost roughly $180 million per year and make the milk industry millions of dollars.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The main concern is the financial interest that the American government has taken in the dairy industry, promoting milk as the best source of calcium. All United States schools that are a part of the federally funded <a href="/wiki/National_School_Lunch_Act" title="National School Lunch Act">National School Lunch Act</a> are required by the federal government to provide milk for all students. The Office of Dietary Supplements recommends that healthy adults between ages 19 and 50 get about 1,000&#160;mg of calcium per day,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> but studies show that the human body can only retain about 550&#160;mg of calcium per day. Milk also contains more excess calories, sugar, and fat than many other sources of calcium.
</p><p>There is also some skepticism of the idea that large doses of calcium provide for healthier bones and teeth. This is a commonly held belief, but there have been some studies that show there is "no connection between the intake of calcium (in any form) and the reduced risk of bone fractures in women aged 34-71 years".<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Another study suggests that calcium supplements do not contribute to bone gain when you surpass a daily intake of 800&#160;mg.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Varieties_and_brands">Varieties and brands</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dairy_Crest_Semi_Skimmed_Milk_Bottle.jpg" title="File:Dairy Crest Semi Skimmed Milk Bottle.jpg">File:Dairy Crest Semi Skimmed Milk Bottle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Glass milk bottle used for home delivery service in the UK.</div></div></div>
<p>Milk products are sold in a number of varieties based on types/degrees of
</p>
<ul>
<li>additives (e.g. vitamins),
</li>
<li>age (e.g. cheddar),
</li>
<li>coagulation (e.g. cottage cheese),
</li>
<li>farming method (e.g. organic, grass-fed).
</li>
<li>fat content (e.g. half and half),
</li>
<li>fermentation (e.g. buttermilk),
</li>
<li>flavoring (e.g. chocolate),
</li>
<li>homogenization (e.g. cream top),
</li>
<li>reduction or elimination of lactose,
</li>
<li>mammal (e.g. cow, goat, sheep),
</li>
<li>packaging (e.g. bottle),
</li>
<li>pasteurization (e.g. raw milk),
</li>
<li>water content (e.g. dry milk)
</li>
</ul>
<p>Milk preserved by the <a href="/wiki/Ultra-high-temperature_processing" title="Ultra-high-temperature processing">UHT</a> process does not need to be refrigerated before opening and has a longer shelf life than milk in ordinary packaging. It is typically sold unrefrigerated in the UK, US, Europe, Latin America, and Australia.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reduction_or_elimination_of_lactose">Reduction or elimination of lactose</span></h3>
<p>Lactose-free milk can be produced by passing milk over lactase enzyme bound to an inert carrier. Once the molecule is cleaved, there are no lactose ill effects. Forms are available with reduced amounts of lactose (typically 30% of normal), and alternatively with nearly 0%. The only noticeable difference from regular milk is a slightly sweeter taste due to the generation of glucose by lactose cleavage. It does not, however, contain more glucose, and is nutritionally identical to regular milk.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, where approximately 17% of the Finnish-speaking population has hypolactasia,<sup id="cite_ref-Sahi2_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sahi2-118">[118]</a></sup> has had "HYLA" (acronym for <i>hydrolysed lactose</i>) products available for many years. Lactose of low-lactose level cow's milk products, ranging from ice cream to cheese, is enzymatically hydrolysed into glucose and galactose. The ultra-pasteurization process, combined with aseptic packaging, ensures a long shelf life. In 2001, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valio (page does not exist)">Valio</a> launched a lactose-free milk drink that is not sweet like HYLA milk but has the fresh taste of ordinary milk. Valio patented the <a href="/wiki/Chromatography" title="Chromatography">chromatographic</a> separation method to remove lactose. Valio also markets these products in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estonia (page does not exist)">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>, where the company says <a href="/wiki/Ultrafiltration" title="Ultrafiltration">ultrafiltration</a> is used.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the UK, where an estimated 15% of the population are affected by lactose intolerance,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactofree&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactofree (page does not exist)">Lactofree</a> produces milk, cheese, and yogurt products that contain only 0.03% lactose.
</p><p>To aid digestion in those with <a href="/wiki/Lactose_intolerance" title="Lactose intolerance">lactose intolerance</a>, milk with added bacterial cultures such as <i><a href="/wiki/Lactobacillus_acidophilus" title="Lactobacillus acidophilus">Lactobacillus acidophilus</a></i> ("acidophilus milk") and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bifidobacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bifidobacteria (page does not exist)">bifidobacteria</a> ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=A/B_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A/B milk (page does not exist)">a/B milk</a>") is available in some areas.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> Another milk with <i><a href="/wiki/Lactococcus_lactis" title="Lactococcus lactis">Lactococcus lactis</a></i> bacteria cultures ("<a href="/wiki/Buttermilk" title="Buttermilk">cultured buttermilk</a>") often is used in cooking to replace the traditional use of naturally <a href="/wiki/Soured_milk" title="Soured milk">soured milk</a>, which has become rare due to the ubiquity of pasteurization, which also kills the naturally occurring Lactococcus bacteria.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Additives_and_flavoring">Additives and flavoring</span></h3>
<p>In areas where the cattle (and often the people) live indoors, commercially sold milk commonly has <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin D (page does not exist)">vitamin D</a> added to it to make up for lack of exposure to <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet">UVB</a> radiation.
</p><p>Reduced-fat milks often have added <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_A_palmitate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin A palmitate (page does not exist)">vitamin A palmitate</a> to compensate for the loss of the vitamin during fat removal; in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> this results in reduced fat milks having a higher vitamin A content than whole milk.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>Milk often has <a href="/wiki/Flavoring" title="Flavoring" class="mw-redirect">flavoring</a> added to it for better taste or as a means of improving sales. <a href="/wiki/Chocolate_milk" title="Chocolate milk">Chocolate milk</a> has been sold for many years and has been followed more recently by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Strawberry_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Strawberry milk (page does not exist)">strawberry milk</a> and others. Some nutritionists have criticized flavored milk for adding sugar, usually in the form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=High-fructose_corn_syrup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High-fructose corn syrup (page does not exist)">high-fructose corn syrup</a>, to the diets of children who are already commonly obese in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Distribution">Distribution</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Glass_milk_bottles.jpg" title="File:Glass milk bottles.jpg">File:Glass milk bottles.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Returning reusable glass <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_bottle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk bottle (page does not exist)">milk bottles</a>, used for home delivery service in the UK</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Milk-bottle.jpg" title="File:Milk-bottle.jpg">File:Milk-bottle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A glass <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_bottle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk bottle (page does not exist)">bottle</a> of non-homogenized, organic, local milk from a farm in <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, in the United States. American milk bottles are generally rectangular in shape</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kirkland_Milk_Jug.JPG" title="File:Kirkland Milk Jug.JPG">File:Kirkland Milk Jug.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Square_milk_jug&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Square milk jug (page does not exist)">rectangular milk jug</a> design used by <a href="/wiki/Costco" title="Costco">Costco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sam%27s_Club" title="Sam's Club">Sam's Club</a> stores in the United States which allows for stacking and display of filled containers rather than being shipped to the store in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_crate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk crate (page does not exist)">milk crates</a> and manual loading into a freezer display rack.</div></div></div>
<p>Due to the short shelf life of normal milk, it used to be delivered to households daily in many countries; however, improved refrigeration at home, changing food shopping patterns because of supermarkets, and the higher cost of home delivery mean that daily deliveries by a <a href="/wiki/Milkman" title="Milkman">milkman</a> are no longer available in most countries.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia_and_New_Zealand">Australia and New Zealand</span></h4>
<p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a>, prior to "metrification", milk was generally distributed in 1 pint (568ml) glass bottles. In Australia and in Ireland there was a government funded "free milk for school children" program, and milk was distributed at morning recess in 1/3 pint bottles. With the conversion to metric measures, the milk industry were concerned that the replacement of the pint bottles with 500ml bottles would result in a 13.6% drop in milk consumption; hence, all pint bottles were recalled and replaced by 600 mL bottles. With time, due to the steadily increasing cost of collecting, transporting, storing and cleaning glass bottles, they were replaced by cardboard cartons. A number of designs were used, including a tetrahedron which could be close-packed without waste space, and could not be knocked over accidentally. (slogan: No more crying over spilt milk.) However, the industry eventually settled on a design similar to that used in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-wwwa_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwwa-125">[125]</a></sup> Milk is now available in a variety of sizes in cardboard cartons (250&#160;mL, 375&#160;mL, 600&#160;mL, 1 liter and 1.5 liters) and plastic bottles (1, 2 and 3 liters). A significant addition to the marketplace has been "long-life" milk (<a href="/wiki/UHT" title="UHT" class="mw-redirect">UHT</a>), generally available in 1 and 2 liter rectangular cardboard cartons. In urban and suburban areas where there is sufficient demand, home delivery is still available, though in suburban areas this is often 3 times per week rather than daily. Another significant and popular addition to the marketplace has been flavored milks – for example, as mentioned above, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Farmers_Union_Iced_Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Farmers Union Iced Coffee (page does not exist)">Farmers Union Iced Coffee</a> outsells <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a> in <a href="/wiki/South_Australia" title="South Australia">South Australia</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="India">India</span></h4>
<p>In rural <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, milk is home delivered, daily, by local milkmen carrying bulk quantities in a metal container, usually on a bicycle. In other parts of metropolitan <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, milk is usually bought or delivered in plastic bags or cartons via shops or supermarkets.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pakistan">Pakistan</span></h4>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, milk is supplied in jugs. Milk has been a staple food, especially among the pastoral tribes in this country.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="United_Kingdom">United Kingdom</span></h4>
<p>Since the late 1990s, milk-buying patterns have changed drastically in the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">UK</a>. The classic <a href="/wiki/Milkman" title="Milkman">milkman</a>, who travels his local <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_round&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk round (page does not exist)">milk round</a> (route) using a <a href="/wiki/Milk_float" title="Milk float">milk float</a> (often battery powered) during the early hours and delivers milk in 1 <a href="/wiki/Pint" title="Pint">pint</a> glass bottles with <a href="/wiki/Aluminium_foil" title="Aluminium foil">aluminium foil</a> tops directly to households, has almost disappeared.
The main reasons for the decline of UK home deliveries by milkmen are household refrigerators (which lessen the need for daily milk deliveries) and private car usage (which has increased supermarket shopping). In 1996, more than 2.5 billion liters of milk were still being delivered by milkmen, but by 2006 only 637 million liters (13% of milk consumed) was delivered by some 9,500 milkmen.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> By 2010, the estimated number of milkmen had dropped to 6,000.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> Assuming that delivery per milkman is the same as it was in 2006, this means milkmen deliveries now only account for 6–7% of all milk consumed by UK households (6.7 billion liters in 2008/2009).<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>Almost 95% of all milk in the UK is thus sold in shops today, most of it in plastic bottles of various sizes, but some also in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_carton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk carton (page does not exist)">milk cartons</a>. Milk is hardly ever sold in glass bottles in UK shops.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">United States</span></h4>
<p>In the United States, glass milk bottles have been replaced mostly with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_carton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk carton (page does not exist)">milk cartons</a> and plastic jugs. Gallons of milk are almost always sold in jugs, while half gallons and quarts may be found in both paper cartons and plastic jugs, and smaller sizes are almost always in cartons.
</p><p>The "half pint" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> milk carton is the traditional unit as a component of school lunches, though some companies have replaced that unit size with a plastic bottle, which is also available at retail in 6- and 12-pack size.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Packaging">Packaging</span></h3>
<p>Glass milk bottles are now rare. Most people purchase milk in bags, plastic bottles, or plastic-coated paper cartons. <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet">Ultraviolet</a> (UV) light from <a href="/wiki/Fluorescent_lamp" title="Fluorescent lamp">fluorescent lighting</a> can alter the flavor of milk, so many companies that once distributed milk in <a href="/wiki/Transparency_and_translucency" title="Transparency and translucency">transparent</a> or highly <a href="/wiki/Translucent" title="Translucent" class="mw-redirect">translucent</a> containers are now using thicker materials that block the UV light.
Milk comes in a variety of <a href="/wiki/Carton" title="Carton">containers</a> with local variants:
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Distributed in a variety of sizes, most commonly in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aseptic_processing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aseptic processing (page does not exist)">aseptic</a> cartons for up to 1.5 liters, and plastic screw-top bottles beyond that with the following volumes; 1.1&#160;L, 2&#160;L, and 3&#160;L. 1 liter <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_bag&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk bag (page does not exist)">milk bags</a> are starting to appear in supermarkets, but have not yet proved popular. Most UHT-milk is packed in 1 or 2 liter paper containers with a sealed plastic spout.<sup id="cite_ref-wwwa_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwwa-125">[125]</a></sup>
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Used to be sold in cooled 1 liter bags, just like in <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Africa (page does not exist)">South Africa</a>. Today the most common form is 1 liter aseptic cartons containing UHT skimmed, semi-skimmed or whole milk, although the plastic bags are still in use for pasteurized milk. Higher grades of pasteurized milk can be found in cartons or plastic bottles. Sizes other than 1 liter are rare.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> 1.33 liter plastic bags (sold as 4 liters in 3 bags) are widely available in some areas (especially the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maritimes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maritimes (page does not exist)">Maritimes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">Ontario</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quebec&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quebec (page does not exist)">Quebec</a>), although the 4 liter plastic jug has supplanted them in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western Canada (page does not exist)">western Canada</a>. Other common packaging sizes are 2 liter, 1 liter, 500 mL, and 250 mL cartons, as well as 4 liter, 1 liter, 250&#160;mL aseptic cartons and 500&#160;mL plastic jugs.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Distributed most commonly in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aseptic_processing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aseptic processing (page does not exist)">aseptic</a> cartons for up to 1 liter, but smaller, snack-sized cartons are also popular. The most common flavors, besides the natural presentation, are chocolate, strawberry and vanilla.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Sweetened milk is a drink popular with students of all ages and is often sold in small plastic bags complete with straw. Adults not wishing to drink at a banquet often drink milk served from cartons or <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong-style_milk_tea" title="Hong Kong-style milk tea">milk tea</a>.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> sells milk in 1 liter plastic bags.
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> UHT milk (<i>trajno mlijeko/trajno mleko/</i>трајно млеко) is sold in 500&#160;mL and 1&#160;L (sometimes also 200 ml) aseptic cartons. Non-UHT pasteurized milk (<i>svježe mlijeko/sveže mleko/</i>свеже млеко) is most commonly sold in 1&#160;L and 1.5&#160;L PET bottles, though in Serbia one can still find milk in plastic bags.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> Parts of <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Sizes of 500 mL, 1 liter (the most common), 1.5 liters, 2 liters and 3 liters are commonplace.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in 1 L or 1.5 L cartons, in some places also in 2&#160;dl and 5&#160;dl cartons.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Milk is sold in glass bottles (220 mL), cartons (236 mL and 1&#160;L), plastic jugs (2 liters) and aseptic cartons (250&#160;mL).
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in 500 mL plastic bags and in bottles in some parts like in west. It is still customary to serve the milk boiled, despite pasteurization. Milk is often buffalo milk. Flavored milk is sold in most convenience stores in waxed cardboard containers. Convenience stores also sell many varieties of milk (such as flavored and ultra-pasteurized) in different sizes, usually in aseptic cartons.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Usually sold in 1 liter cartons, but smaller, snack-sized cartons are available.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Non-UHT milk is most commonly sold in 1 liter waxed cardboard boxes and 1 liter plastic bags. It may also be found in 0.5&#160;L and 2&#160;L waxed cardboard boxes, 2&#160;L plastic jugs and 1 L plastic bottles. UHT milk is available in 1 liter (and less commonly also in 0.25&#160;L) carton "bricks".
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in 1 liter waxed paperboard cartons. In most city centers there is also <a href="/wiki/Delivery_(commerce)" title="Delivery (commerce)">home delivery</a> of milk in glass jugs. As seen in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, sweetened and flavored milk drinks are commonly seen in <a href="/wiki/Vending_machine" title="Vending machine">vending machines</a>.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Sold in cartons (180&#160;mL, 200&#160;mL, 500&#160;mL 900&#160;mL, 1&#160;L, 1.8&#160;L, 2.3&#160;L), plastic jugs (1&#160;L and 1.8&#160;L), aseptic cartons (180 mL and 200 mL) and plastic bags (1 L).
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Milk is supplied in 500 mL Plastic bags and carried in Jugs from rural to cities and sell
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Milk is supplied in 1000 mL Plastic bottles and delivered from factories to cities and sell
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chocomilkjf.JPG" title="File:Chocomilkjf.JPG">File:Chocomilkjf.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">PCC Dairy Choco Milk, pasteurized, non-homogenized, made from fresh water buffalo milk <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philippine_Carabao_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philippine Carabao Center (page does not exist)">Philippine Carabao Center</a>.</div></div></div>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> UHT milk is mostly sold in aseptic cartons (500&#160;mL, 1&#160;L, 2&#160;L), and non-UHT in 1&#160;L plastic bags or plastic bottles. Milk, UHT is commonly boiled, despite being pasteurized.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Africa (page does not exist)">South Africa</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in 1 liter bags. The bag is then placed in a plastic jug and the corner cut off before the milk is poured.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in 0.3&#160;L, 1&#160;L or 1.5&#160;L cartons and sometimes as plastic or glass milk bottles.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in 500 mL or 1L cartons or special plastic bottles. UHT milk is more popular. Milkmen also serve in smaller towns and villages.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Most stores stock <a href="/wiki/Imperial_units" title="Imperial units">imperial</a> sizes: 1 pint (568&#160;mL, 2 pints (1.136&#160;L), 4 pints (2.273&#160;L), 6 pints (3.408&#160;L) or a combination including both metric and imperial sizes. Glass milk bottles delivered to the doorstep by the milkman are typically pint-sized and are returned empty by the householder for repeated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reuse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reuse (page does not exist)">reuse</a>. Milk is sold at supermarkets in either aseptic cartons or HDPE bottles. Supermarkets have also now begun to introduce milk in bags, to be poured from a proprietary jug and nozzle.
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in <a href="/wiki/Gallon" title="Gallon">gallon</a> (3.78&#160;L), half-gallon (1.89&#160;L) and <a href="/wiki/Quart" title="Quart">quart</a> (0.94&#160;L) containers of natural-colored HDPE resin, or, for sizes less than one gallon, cartons of waxed paperboard. Bottles made of opaque <a href="/wiki/Polyethylene_terephthalate" title="Polyethylene terephthalate">PET</a> are also becoming commonplace for smaller, particularly metric, sizes such as one liter. The US single-serving size is usually the half-pint (about 240 mL). Less frequently, dairies deliver milk directly to consumers, from coolers filled with glass bottles which are typically half-gallon sized and returned for reuse. Some <a href="/wiki/Convenience_store" title="Convenience store">convenience store</a> chains in the United States (such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kwik_Trip&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kwik Trip (page does not exist)">Kwik Trip</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Midwest" title="Midwest" class="mw-redirect">Midwest</a>) sell milk in half-gallon bags, while another <a href="/w/index.php?title=Square_milk_jug&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Square milk jug (page does not exist)">rectangular cube gallon container design</a> used for easy stacking in shipping and displaying is used by <a href="/wiki/Warehouse_club" title="Warehouse club">warehouse clubs</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Costco" title="Costco">Costco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sam%27s_Club" title="Sam's Club">Sam's Club</a>, along with some <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wal-Mart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wal-Mart (page does not exist)">Wal-Mart</a> stores.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd> Commonly sold in 1 liter bags. The bag is then placed in a plastic jug and the corner cut off before the milk is poured.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Practically everywhere, <a href="/wiki/Condensed_milk" title="Condensed milk">condensed milk</a> and evaporated milk are distributed in metal cans, 250 and 125&#160;mL paper containers and 100 and 200&#160;mL squeeze tubes, and <a href="/wiki/Powdered_milk" title="Powdered milk">powdered milk</a> (skim and whole) is distributed in boxes or bags.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spoilage_and_fermented_milk_products">Spoilage and fermented milk products</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yakult_brazil.jpg" title="File:Yakult brazil.jpg">File:Yakult brazil.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Yakult" title="Yakult">Yakult</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Probiotic" title="Probiotic">probiotic</a> milk-like product made by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (food) (page does not exist)">fermenting</a> a mixture of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Skimmed_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skimmed milk (page does not exist)">skimmed milk</a> with a special strain of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacterium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacterium (page does not exist)">bacterium</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactobacillus_casei&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactobacillus casei (page does not exist)">Lactobacillus casei</a> Shirota</i>.</div></div></div>
<p>When <a href="/wiki/Raw_milk" title="Raw milk">raw milk</a> is left standing for a while, it turns "<a href="/wiki/Sour" title="Sour" class="mw-redirect">sour</a>". This is the result of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (food) (page does not exist)">fermentation</a>, where <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactic_acid_bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactic acid bacteria (page does not exist)">lactic acid bacteria</a> ferment the <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">lactose</a> in the milk into <a href="/wiki/Lactic_acid" title="Lactic acid">lactic acid</a>. Prolonged fermentation may render the milk unpleasant to consume. This fermentation process is exploited by the introduction of bacterial cultures (e.g. <i><a href="/wiki/Lactobacilli" title="Lactobacilli" class="mw-redirect">Lactobacilli</a> sp., <a href="/wiki/Streptococcus" title="Streptococcus">Streptococcus</a> sp., <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leuconostoc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leuconostoc (page does not exist)">Leuconostoc</a> sp.</i>, etc.) to produce a variety of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermented_milk_products&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermented milk products (page does not exist)">fermented milk products</a>. The reduced pH from lactic acid accumulation denatures proteins and causes the milk to undergo a variety of different transformations in appearance and texture, ranging from an aggregate to smooth consistency. Some of these products include <a href="/wiki/Sour_cream" title="Sour cream">sour cream</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheese (page does not exist)">cheese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buttermilk" title="Buttermilk">buttermilk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Viili" title="Viili">viili</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kefir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kefir (page does not exist)">kefir</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kumis" title="Kumis">kumis</a>. <i>See <a href="/wiki/Dairy_product" title="Dairy product">Dairy product</a></i> for more information.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pasteurization" title="Pasteurization">Pasteurization</a> of cow's milk initially destroys any potential pathogens and increases the shelf life,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} but eventually results in spoilage that makes it unsuitable for consumption. This causes it to assume an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unpleasant_odor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unpleasant odor (page does not exist)">unpleasant odor</a>, and the milk is deemed non-consumable due to unpleasant taste and an increased risk of <a href="/wiki/Food_poisoning" title="Food poisoning" class="mw-redirect">food poisoning</a>. In raw milk, the presence of <a href="/wiki/Lactic_acid" title="Lactic acid">lactic acid</a>-producing bacteria, under suitable conditions, ferments the lactose present to lactic acid. The increasing <a href="/wiki/Acid" title="Acid">acidity</a> in turn prevents the growth of other organisms, or slows their growth significantly. During pasteurization, however, these lactic acid bacteria are mostly destroyed.
</p><p>In order to prevent spoilage, milk can be kept <a href="/wiki/Refrigerator" title="Refrigerator">refrigerated</a> and stored between 1 and 4 degrees Celsius in <a href="/wiki/Bulk_tank" title="Bulk tank">bulk tanks</a>. Most milk is pasteurized by heating briefly and then refrigerated to allow transport from <a href="/wiki/Factory_farming" title="Factory farming" class="mw-redirect">factory farms</a> to local markets. The spoilage of milk can be forestalled by using ultra-high temperature (<a href="/wiki/UHT" title="UHT" class="mw-redirect">UHT</a>) treatment. Milk so treated can be stored unrefrigerated for several months until opened but has a characteristic "cooked" taste. <a href="/wiki/Condensed_milk" title="Condensed milk">Condensed milk</a>, made by removing most of the water, can be stored in cans for many years, unrefrigerated, as can <a href="/wiki/Evaporated_milk" title="Evaporated milk">evaporated milk</a>. The most durable form of milk is <a href="/wiki/Powdered_milk" title="Powdered milk">powdered milk</a>, which is produced from milk by removing almost all <a href="/wiki/Water" title="Water">water</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Moisture_content" title="Moisture content" class="mw-redirect">moisture content</a> is usually less than 5% in both drum- and spray-dried powdered milk.
</p>
<center><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 210px"><div style="width: 210px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 205px;">Milk in a Japanese supermarket.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Refrigerated milk
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 210px"><div style="width: 210px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 205px;">Milk powder Incolac.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Incolac powdered milk
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 210px"><div style="width: 210px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 205px;">Iryska.png</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>A can of condensed milk
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 210px"><div style="width: 210px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 205px;">Tin of condensed milk.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>An opened can of condensed milk
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 210px"><div style="width: 210px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 205px;">Gezuckerte-Kondensmilch BMK.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Condensed milk in a tube
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul></center>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Language_and_culture">Language and culture</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:From_Abhisheka_To_Panchamrutha.jpg" title="File:From Abhisheka To Panchamrutha.jpg">File:From Abhisheka To Panchamrutha.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Hindu <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abhisheka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abhisheka (page does not exist)">Abhisheka</a> ritual in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agara,_Bangalore_Rural&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agara, Bangalore Rural (page does not exist)">Agara</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bangalore_Rural_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bangalore Rural District (page does not exist)">Bangalore Rural District</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The importance of milk in human culture is attested to by the numerous expressions embedded in our languages, for example, "the milk of human kindness". In ancient <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greek_mythology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greek mythology (page does not exist)">Greek mythology</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Goddess" title="Goddess">goddess</a> <a href="/wiki/Hera" title="Hera">Hera</a> spilled her <a href="/wiki/Breast" title="Breast">breast</a> milk after refusing to feed <a href="/wiki/Heracles" title="Heracles">Heracles</a>, resulting in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Milky_Way&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milky Way (page does not exist)">Milky Way</a>.
</p><p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Africa (page does not exist)">African</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asian</a> <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butter" title="Butter">butter</a> is traditionally made from fermented milk rather than cream. It can take several hours of churning to produce workable butter grains from fermented milk.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>Holy books have also mentioned milk. The Bible contains references to the '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Land_of_Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Land of Israel (page does not exist)">Land of Milk and Honey</a>'. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qur%27an&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qur'an (page does not exist)">Qur'an</a>, there is a request to wonder on milk as follows: 'And surely in the livestock there is a lesson for you, We give you to drink of that which is in their bellies from the midst of digested food and blood, pure milk palatable for the drinkers.'(16-The Honeybee, 66). The <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a> fast is traditionally broken with a glass of milk and dates.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abhisheka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abhisheka (page does not exist)">Abhisheka</a> is conducted by <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hindu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jain</a> priests, by pouring libations on the <a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">image of a deity</a> being worshipped, amidst the chanting of <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a>. Usually offerings such as milk, <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghee" title="Ghee">ghee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honey" title="Honey">honey</a> may be poured among other offerings depending on the type of abhishekam being performed.
</p><p>To milk someone, in the vernacular of many English-speaking countries, is to take advantage of the person.
</p><p>The word "milk" has had many slang meanings over time. In the 19th century, milk was used to describe a cheap alcoholic drink made from methylated spirits mixed with water. The word was also used to mean defraud, to be idle, to intercept telegrams addressed to someone else, and a weakling or 'milksop'. In the mid-1930s, the word was used in Australia meaning to siphon gas from a car.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_uses">Other uses</span></h2>
<p>Besides serving as a beverage or source of food, milk has been described as used by farmers and gardeners as an organic <a href="/wiki/Fungicide" title="Fungicide">fungicide</a> and foliage fertilizer.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Verify_credibility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Verify credibility (page does not exist)">Template:Verify credibility</a> Diluted milk solutions have been demonstrated to provide an effective method of preventing powdery mildew on grape vines, while showing it is unlikely to harm the plant.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bibliography">Bibliography</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> Dupuis, E. Melanie. <i>Nature's Perfect Food</i> (2002) <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.amazon.com/Natures-Perfect-Food-Melanie-Dupuis/dp/0814719384/">excerpt and text search</a>
</li>
<li> Kardashian, Kirk. <i>Milk Money: Cash, Cows, and the Death of the American Dairy Farm</i> (2012) <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.amazon.com/Milk-Money-Death-American-Dairy/dp/1611680271/">excerpt and text search</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li> Smith-Howard, Kendra. <i>Pure and Modern Milk: An Environmental History Since 1900</i> (Oxford University Press; 2013) 229 pages; A study of milk control in the United States, 
</li>
<li> Valenze, Deborah. <i>Milk: A Local and Global History</i> (Yale University Press, 2011) 368 pp. 
</li>
<li> Wiley, Andrea. <i>Re-imagining Milk: Cultural and Biological Perspectives</i> (Routledge 2010) (Series for Creative Teaching and Learning in Anthropology) <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.amazon.com/Re-imagining-Milk-Biological-Perspectives-Anthropology/dp/0415806577/">excerpt and text search</a>
</li>
<li> United States. Office of Dietary Supplements. Dietary Supplement Fact Sheet: Calcium. 2013. Web. &lt;<a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Calcium-HealthProfessional/">http://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Calcium-HealthProfessional/</a>&gt;.
</li>
<li> Feskanich, D., WC Willett, MJ Stampfer, and GA Colditz. 1997. "Milk, dietary calcium, and bone fractures in women: a 12-year prospective study." <i>American Journal of Public Health.</i> Vol 87, Issue 6. 992-997
</li>
</ul>

<div class="portal" role="navigation" id='p-tb' aria-labelledby='p-tb-label'>
	<h3 id='p-tb-label'>Tools</h3>
	<div class="body">
		<ul>
			<li id="t-whatlinkshere"><a href="/wiki/Special:WhatLinksHere/Milk" title="A list of all wiki pages that link here [j]" accesskey="j">What links here</a></li>
